chapter.title: Module 5 Learning Objectives
chapter.content:
Module 5 Learning Objectives


Now it’s time for you to put together what you have learned and what you have done so far to make a final lesson plan. Here are the learning objectives for this module.


By the end of this lesson, participants will be able to:

  1. produce a final lesson plan containing the learning objectives, assessments and activities produced in previous modules

  2. achieve a score of at least 21 out of 27 points, using provided rubric for evaluation

  3. write a reflection on how the learning in this course shaped the lesson plan you produced

  4. if possible, teach and write a reflection on the success of the lesson

chapter.title: Creating a Final Lesson Plan
chapter.content:
Creating a Final Lesson Plan

You have already produced the major elements of your lesson plan – learning objectives, assessments, and activities. It only remains to write it up. Two additional lesson plans from previous DI courses are provided as models:  one for high school-level science, and one for writing a persuasive paragraph.  Each of these lesson plans contains a rubric which, while instructive as an exercise, is not required. In writing the lesson plan, you may use the template geared specifically to this course if you find it helpful. You may also want to explore this electronic lesson planner on LINCS (you need to create a log in and password):  https://lessonplanner.lincs.ed.gov/.  Any lesson plan format may be used that allows fulfillment of the assessment requirements.

As an additional aid in planning, a version of the rubric used to evaluate all the model lesson plans is included in this course. You can use this to evaluate your own lesson plan. Remember to follow the rubric principles discussed earlier and make it available before work is completed as a guide to exactly what is required.

 

Learn More About It

If you are interested in reading a discussion thread among practitioners and researchers concerning the creation and use of rubrics, which also contains links to examples, visit this LINCS Community:  https://community.lincs.ed.gov/discussion/checklists-and-rubrics-more-discussion-resources-strategies

chapter.title: Evaluating Your Plan
chapter.content:
Evaluating Your Plan

Now it’s time to sit back and contemplate what you’ve done. Are your learning objectives specific, observable and measurable? Have you addressed readiness in a way that meets the needs of all your students? Does your summative assessment match your learning objectives? Do your activities lead students toward the learning objectives? Have you differentiated the content and/or process of your activities? Do all students have access to the topic?

To help with this evaluation, consult the self-evaluation rubric introduced above that you used to guide your final planning. The aim is to produce a lesson that scores at least 21 out of 27 points. As models, the final evaluation for the Science lesson plan and the final evaluation for the Paragraph Writing lesson plan are included, complete with teacher comments. The rubrics differ somewhat from your self-evaluation because these lessons were required to contain rubrics, which were scored and commented on in the evaluations.

The purpose of this course was to provide guidance in producing a differentiated lesson plan. Of course, the most important result will take place outside its purview - actually teaching the lesson. You will certainly learn a great deal from the experience, and you may want to share with others who have been through this course, either online or among colleagues at your workplace. The saying has it that many hands make light work; in this context, we could say that many minds make great teaching.

chapter.title: Review, Tasks, and Resources
chapter.content:
Review, Tasks, and Resources

Tasks

  1. Complete a lesson plan containing the learning objectives, assessments and activities produced in previous modules.

  2. Score at least 21 out of 27 points on the provided evaluation rubric.

  3. Write a reflection on how the learning in this course shaped the lesson plan you produced. Post it in the COP: https://community.lincs.ed.gov/discussion/online-course-differentiated-instruction-and-lesson-planning

  4. Respond to a post from another participant concerning his/her experience in applying DI in practice.

  5. If possible, write a reflection on the success of your lesson. Post it in the COP: https://community.lincs.ed.gov/discussion/online-course-differentiated-instruction-and-lesson-planning
